Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Grants for 2017 N^2Women Workshop and Meetings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports students at U.S. institutions to attend meetings of the Networking Networking Women (N^2Women) organization.
The purpose of the N^2 Women meetings and workshops is to foster connections among women in the communications and networking
research fields. Each meeting will be co-located with a premier networking conference in 2017:
IEEE INFOCOM 2017 in Atlanta, GA, ICCCN 2017 in Vancouver, Canada, and ACM SIGCOMM 2017 in Los Angeles, CA.

The intellectual merit of this activity resides in the contributions that the student participants will make to
(1) the N^2Women meetings, (2) the premier co-located conferences, and (3) the future scientific progress of the student's research.
Participant support funds will allow these graduate students to attend high-quality technical presentations,
be exposed to state-of-the-art research, and interact with leading researchers and fellow graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The funding was requested to support students at U.S. institutions to attend the N2Women Meetings and Workshops. We have accomplished following outcomes:

  • We have sponsored 11 PhD female students from different universities to attend the The Sixth Networking Networking Women (N2Women) Professional Development Workshop, which is a a full-day, co-educational, professional development workshop to be co-located with SIGCOMM 2017 in Los Angeles, CA. According to the participants survey, more than 90% agree that the workshop has provided new things to their experience.
  • In this N2Women workshop, we invited Professor Anja Feldman (TU Berlin, Germany) to give a keynote on ?The Internet: A complex system at its imits.? She first outlined the evolution
    a number of surprises of the Internet, and discussed methods for detecting Internet infrastructure outages, how to extend software-defined networking concepts to wireless networking, how to
    achieve predictable performance in distributed systems. Finally, she gave an outlook on how we may evolve the Internet to tackle the future challenges of ubiquitous data availability from sensors
    and devices everywhere. We also invited Professor Wenjing Lou (Virginia Tech) to give a keynote on ?The minority advantages: Benefits of being a female professor in science.? In this talk, she
    shared with all participants about her 14 years of career experience as a female science professor and discussed on how being a minority can be an advantage in your career development, and ways to make it happen (i.e., a recipe of turning the lemons into lemonade). In addition, she shared her
    role as a NSF program director, which offered a broad view of wireless networking and security research and funding opportunities from the perspective of NSF investment in these areas.
  • In this workshop, we have developed a mentor/mentee program.
    We would like to extend mentoring throughout the week for the students who are staying for SIGCOMM. In this case,
    we are hoping to find mentors who can host mentees with similar research interests during the main SIGCOMM conference and workshops. Here is the list of the first batch of mentors:
    Ethan Katz-bassett USC/Columbia;  George Porter UCSD
    Karen Sollins MIT; Keith Winstein Stanford Univ.
    James Mickens; Harvard Univ.
    Jiasi Chen; UCR
    Justine Sherry; CMU
    Marco Canini; KAUST
    Rachit Agarwal; Cornell
    Samantha Lo; Google
    Sami Rollins; University of San Francisco
    Te-Yuan Huang; Netflix
    Yashar Ganjali; Toronto Univ.
    Ying Zhang; Facebook
  • We have sponsored N2Women meeting at IEEE INFOCOM 2018, which was held in 15-19 April 2018. This meeting is organized Anna Wisniewska (The Graduate Center at the City University
    of New York, USA) and faculty mentor Professor Wenjing Lou (Virginia Tech, USA). We invited Professor Yingying (Jennifer) Chen (Rutgers University, USA) to give a keynote on ?Leadership
    and Diversity: How do we advance diversity in leadership?? and a panel discussion with Wenye Wang (North Carolina State University), Tilman Wolf (University of Massachusetts Amherst),
    Qian Zhang (Hong Kong University of Science and Technology), and Jack Brassil (National Science Foundation, USA).
  • We have sponsored the joint 7th N2Women and WICE: Professional Development Workshop in Kansas City, MO. This is jointly sponsored with IEEE Communication Society. In this event, we have sponsored 10 female students to attend the meeting. Two keynote speakers were invited: Dr. Vanitha Kumar (Vice President-Software Engineering, Qualcomm Technologies Incorporated) on ?Road to Innovvation Super Highway, ?ROAD TO INNOVATION SUPER HIGHWAY and Dr. Monisha Ghosh (Program Director, NSF) on ?What?s Next for Wireless Networking Research?? The panel is on ?In the crowd of hard-working and excellent researchers: what can we do to stand out? ? which
    is moderated by Prof. Ana Garc ́ıa Armada.
